items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: The Flood Alert for the River Foulness and Market Weighton is no longer in force as river levels have fallen. Some showers are forecast for Sunday night 23/10/2022 and Monday morning 24/10/2022. We will continue to monitor the situation.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. 
The first forecast high water is at 10:15 AM on Tuesday 25/10/2022 with a level of 1.21mAODN with southerly force 5 winds. The second forecast high water is at 09:45 PM on Tuesday 25/10/2022 with a level of 1.27mAODN with south-easterly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)
Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of these times.
We are closing locks and flood gates in the area.
It is forecast that the tide between 09:30 AM and Midday on Wednesday 26/10/2022 will be higher than Tuesdays tides and is forecast to reach 1.43mAODN.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Consider activating any property flood protection products in Christchurch Harbour.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 26/10/2022, or as the situation changes.

"This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels are below the flood risk threshold and are forecast to remain below the threshold despite further rain this evening, 23/10/22. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further thunderstorms are forecast until the early hours of tomorrow morning, with low confidence over exact timing and locations. 
We continue to monitor the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the upper River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is expected today, 24/10/22, in the Godalming area. The forecast for today and tomorrow is for lighter rain showers. Levels have started to fall in the Bordon area and we expect levels to fall in the Godalming area later today. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 24/10/22.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ford Green Brook, Lyme Brook, River Trent

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Liverpool Road river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 08:00 today, 24/10/22.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Norton Green and Darlaston including Stoke on Trent, Lyme Brook between Newcastle under Lyme and Hanford, Fowlea Brook at Stoke on Trent and Ford Green Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday, 24/10/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. 
Avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lee at Luton, Harpenden and Wheathampstead
items.message:
River levels in the Upper Lee are now falling. A further band of heavy rain impacted the area earlier this evening but did not lead to any further flooding from the river.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected in the Luton area, however there may be areas of standing water that will slowly drain away over the next few days. 
Further showers are forecast for Monday 24th October, but these are not expected to increase river levels.
We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather forecasts, and will issue any new flood messages when needed.
This message will automatically be removed after 10 days.

River levels in the River Pinn are now steadily falling. A further band of heavy rain impacted the area earlier this evening but did not lead to any further flooding from the river.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected in areas including Hatch End, Pinner, Ruislip, Ickenham, Hillingdon and Uxbridge, however there may be areas of standing water that will slowly drain away over the next few days. 
Further showers are forecast for Monday 24th October, but these are not expected to increase river levels.
We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather forecasts and will issue any new flood messages when needed.
This message will automatically be removed after 10 days.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further rainfall is possible over the next 12 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast and clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

items.description: Middle Level of the Fens in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk
items.message:
The Chatteris and March rain gauges have recorded significant rainfall over the last 24 hours as a result of the bands of heavy rainfall passing over the catchment. Consequently, flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible over the next couple of days. Areas likely to be affected are Middle Level, including Pondersbridge, Ramsey St Mary’s, Benwick and Welney.

There is potential for some further rainfall today, Monday 24th October, although this is not expected to be significant.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying roads and footpaths which are flooded.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Tuesday 25th October, or as the situation changes.

"River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes."

floodArea.riverOrSea: Bradwell Brook, Dale Brook, Tideswell Brook, Warney Brook and Bentley Brook

items.message:
Small, flashier rivers and streams in the area may respond to heavy rainfall as a result of localised thunderstorms passing through the area. This message has been issued pre-emptively ahead of localised thunderstorms forecast for tonight 23/10/22 and into tomorrow 24/10/22. Given the unpredictable nature of thunderstorms, there is low confidence in the locations and impacts of rainfall at this point. Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams. Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows. 
Thunderstorms are forecast over the next 24 hours, with low confidence over exact timing and locations, followed by light rain on Monday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area and clearing weed screens. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 03:00 tomorrow morning, 24/10/22.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.
Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday 24/10/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 10:45 this evening, 23/10/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   No properties are expected to flood at this time. 
Further showery and at times heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday 24/10/22. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking and clearing weed screens. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  This message will be updated Monday, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Mancetter river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall this morning and further rain overnight. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 21:00 today, 23/10/22.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until Monday afternoon, 24/10/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not expected. River levels remain high but are starting to fall on the Chertsey Bourne following heavy rainfall yesterday. However no further flooding of low lying footpaths, roads and farmland is expected. The forecast for today and tomorrow is for lighter rain showers. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 24/10/22.

River levels have risen at the Basford bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the last 24hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible throughout today 24/10/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.
The current band of rain is expected to clear by 10:00 today, however further rainfall showers are forecast from14:00 this afternoon 24/10/2022. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today 24/10/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated this afternoon, 24/10/22, or as the situation changes.
